es.title: Latin Vibes vs. Spain
es.content: We're using Latin American Spanish here. You might say 'Boleto' for ticket instead of the Spain-style 'Billete', but don't worry—you'll be understood perfectly everywhere.

es.title: The "Ahorita" Trap
es.content: You'll hear 'Ahorita' constantly. It literally means 'little now,' but be careful! It can mean right now, in 10 minutes, or... never. Context is everything!

es.title: Bon Appétit!
es.content: See someone eating? It's super polite to drop a 'Buen provecho' (Enjoy your meal) as you walk by. It’s like a little verbal high-five for their food.

es.title: Say "Mande?"
es.content: In Mexico, shouting 'What?' (¿Qué?) can sound a bit harsh. Try the softer '¿Mande?' (Command me?) or '¿Cómo?' if you didn't hear someone. It's much smoother.

es.title: Don't Rush the Bill
es.content: If the waiter doesn't bring the check, relax! Bringing it early is considered rude (like they're kicking you out). When you're ready, just signal them for 'La cuenta'.

de.title: Any Last Requests?
de.content: At bakeries, you'll hear 'Sonst noch etwas?' It's just the standard 'Anything else?' A simple shake of the head does the trick.

de.title: Cash is (Still) King
de.content: Berlin might be hip, but Germany loves paper money. 'Nur Barzahlung' means Cash Only. Keep some Euros in your pocket or you might go hungry!

de.title: The Polite Letdown
de.content: Germans are direct, but they soften the blow. If you hear 'Leider' (Unfortunately), a polite 'No' is coming right after it.

de.title: Sunday Shutdown
de.content: Heads up: Sundays are 'Ruhetag' (Rest day). Supermarkets and shops are closed. It's the perfect excuse to just hit a café or restaurant.

fr.title: The Golden Rule
fr.content: Walk into a shop? Say 'Bonjour!' immediately. Seriously. If you don't, you're invisible. Say hello, and watch the service magically improve.

fr.title: With This?
fr.content: If the baker asks 'Avec ceci ?', they're just asking if you want anything else to go with your croissant. It’s your cue to order more or pay up.

fr.title: Voilà!
fr.content: You know this one! The French say 'Voilà' for everything—handing you a menu, your coffee, or your change. It’s the verbal period at the end of a sentence.

fr.title: Free H2O
fr.content: Thirsty? Ask for a 'Carafe d'eau' in restaurants. It's free tap water and totally safe. If you ask for 'Eau minérale', you'll be paying for the fancy bottled stuff.

it.title: Nothing Else?
it.content: Italian servers skip the 'Anything else?' and go straight to 'Nient'altro?' (Nothing else?). They're just expecting a 'No' so they can wrap things up.

it.title: Here You Go
it.content: Listen for 'Ecco a lei'. It’s the magic phrase servers use whenever they set something down in front of you. It’s music to a hungry traveler's ears.

it.title: The Cover Charge
it.content: See 'Coperto' on the bill? It’s not a scam! It’s just a standard fee (€1-3) for the bread, cutlery, and the privilege of sitting at the table.

it.title: The Cappuccino Rule
it.content: Ordering a Cappuccino after a big meal? You'll instantly mark yourself as a tourist! Italians strictly drink milk coffees at breakfast only.

ja.title: Keep Your Change
ja.content: Don't tip! Seriously, it confuses people and they might chase you down to return your money. The price is the price.

ja.title: To Go?
ja.content: Instead of 'Take away', you'll usually be asked 'Mochikaeri?' (Take home?). If you're eating there, say 'Tennai' (Inside store).

ja.title: The Soft "No"
ja.content: You won't hear a blunt 'No.' You'll hear 'Moushiwake arimasen' (I have no excuse). It’s the most polite rejection you’ll ever receive.

ja.title: No Wasabi?
ja.content: Want to skip an ingredient? Use 'nuki'. Shout 'Wasabi-nuki' and you'll get your sushi without the spicy green kick.

pl.title: The Swiss Army Word
pl.content: 'Proszę' is the WD-40 of Polish. It means Please, Here you go, Go ahead, and You're welcome. When in doubt, just say Proszę.

pl.title: All Gone
pl.content: If the bakery is empty, they'll say 'Już nie ma' (Already no have). It’s the sad sound of a sold-out donut.

pl.title: Tap to Pay
pl.content: Poland is super digital. You can pay 'Kartą' (With card) almost everywhere, even for a single pack of gum.

pl.title: Just a Sec...
pl.content: Poles love making words cute. Instead of asking for a moment, they'll ask for a 'Chwileczkę' (A tiny little moment). Adorable, right?

pt.title: The ATM Network
pt.content: In Portugal, don't ask for 'card', ask for 'Multibanco'. That's the name of the game (and the network) here.

pt.title: The Appetizer Trap
pt.content: Waiters will drop olives and cheese on your table. Warning: These aren't free! If you eat them, you pay. Not hungry? Just leave them untouched.

pt.title: It Ended
pt.content: If they're out of custard tarts, they'll say 'Acabou' (It ended). Simple, slightly dramatic, and final.

pt.title: Carrying Ingredients
pt.content: Portuguese dishes 'carry' things. You'll hear 'This dish takes (leva) peanuts.' Good to know for allergies!

ru.title: With Self?
ru.content: Want it to go? The phrase is 'S soboy?' which literally translates to 'With self?'. A bit philosophical for a burger, but it works.

ru.title: It Ended
ru.content: Russians don't usually say 'We don't have it.' They say 'Zakonchilos' (It ended). It’s gone. Poof.

ru.title: The Casual "Nope"
ru.content: 'Net' is no, but 'Netu' is the casual way to say 'We’re fresh out' or 'There isn't any.' You'll hear this slang a lot.

ru.title: Tiny Minute
ru.content: If someone asks for a 'Minutochku', they need a 'tiny little minute.' It’s a polite way to put you on hold.

uk.title: The Multitasker
uk.content: 'Proshu' is a heavy lifter. Use it for 'Here you go,' 'You're welcome,' or even 'Come again?' It keeps the conversation flowing.

uk.title: Cash Only
uk.content: 'Hotivka' is the word for cash. If you see 'Lyshe hotivka', put the card away—you're going old school.

uk.title: With Yourself
uk.content: Like their neighbors, Ukrainians refer to takeout as taking food 'Z soboyu' (with yourself).

uk.title: Kill 'em with Kindness
uk.content: Ukrainians love manners. Sprinkle 'Bud laska' (Please) and 'Dyakuyu' (Thank you) everywhere, and you'll fit right in.

zh.title: Phone Eats First
zh.content: Cash is rare! Waiters will point a scanner at you and ask 'Saoma?' (Scan code?). Get your WeChat or Alipay ready.

zh.title: Pack it Up
zh.content: 'Da bao' is the universal word for 'Take away' or boxing up leftovers. It works at street stalls and restaurants alike.

zh.title: Bucks vs. Dollars
zh.content: The money is Yuan, but on the street, everyone calls it 'Kuai.' It's like saying '5 bucks' instead of '5 dollars'.

zh.title: Sold Out!
zh.content: If you hear 'Mai wan le', it means 'Sold out.' Bad luck! You'll have to come back earlier next time.

zh.title: No Tipping
zh.content: Keep your wallet closed after the bill. Tipping isn't a thing in Mainland China, not in restaurants and definitely not in taxis.
